—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether the Australian Government supports the views of the new United States Ambassador to Australia, Mr Lane, that New Zealand's anti-nuclear policy makes it the Hartley of ANZUS and that New Zealand will be readmitted to ANZUS if it gets down on its knees and follows the rules. Does the Minister consider this an appropriate analogy especially when the ANZUS Treaty requires the United States to withdraw from ANZUS if it disagrees with New Zealand's stance, rather than requiring New Zealand's expulsion? Would not the Australian Labor Government agree with its fraternal New Zealand Government when Mr Lange notes that statements such as Mr Lane's serve only to reinforce the New Zealand people's determination to have a nuclear-free and independent country?

—The Australian Government has maintained a position of scrupulous impartiality in the controversy which presently obtains between New Zealand and the United States. We have made our views known to New Zealand on our reaction to the policy issues involved but beyond that we have not sought to mediate or intervene in the dispute in any way. We have not regarded it as appropriate in the past, nor do I regard it as appropriate now, for the Government to comment on the matters that have been raised in the way that they were raised by Senator Vallentine.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether the reports in today's Press are accurate in their anticipation of a worsening of the current account deficit. Is it expected that the figures to be released later this week for the January balance of payments will reveal another large current account deficit? Further, in the light of all the economic indicators, does the Minister still predict that the Budget forecast for a $4.9 billion deficit remains on target?

—Frankly, I have no idea whether the newspaper predictions about the current account deficit for January are correct. However, it is known that there will be some very substantial aircraft purchases in January or possibly February which will cause a short term distortion-a one-off increase in our monthly deficit. On the other question of the Budget projections, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle well knows, it is true that because of the Australian dollar's value being somewhat lower than had been assumed in the Budget figuring, so far this year anyway, outlays will be higher than they would otherwise have been. There have also been some decisions taken by the Government since the Budget was introduced which have increased outlays, and other decisions virtually imposed on the Government by the courts which have increased outlays. But at this stage it is too early to say whether an increase in outlays in some areas will lead to a net increase in outlays. Likewise, even a net increase in outlays will not necessarily mean an increase in the deficit if it is matched by an increase in revenue. In addition, the lower value of the Australian dollar has probably had some positive effects on the revenue side.

—Did the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs see the report in the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday 11 February 1986 entitled `US Military Advisers for the Philippines'? In that article it was reported that the United States of America was considering the despatch of United States military personnel to act as advisers for the Filipino army in its operations against the new people's army. Will the Government state what position Australia holds with respect to United States military advisers being sent to the Philippines?

—The Australian Government has no information to confirm that any specific proposal is being considered by the United States Government for the despatch to the Philippines of military advisers on counter-insurgency. The Press report to which Senator Foreman refers describes the possible despatch of military counter-insurgency advisers as one of a number of options allegedly under study by the United States Department of Defense for improving the capability of the armed forces of the Philippines to combat insurgency. The United States Government has emphasised that its military assistance program to the Philippines is directed towards improving the logistics, mobility and communications of the Philippine armed forces and towards improving military morale and discipline. In testimony to Congress, the United States Administration has pointed out that its assistance program is designed to promote reform and respect for human rights within the Philippine armed forces while improving their capacity to combat insurgency. The Philippines Government has indicated in the past that it does not regard as appropriate the involvement of United States forces in efforts to defeat the insurgency. It is also evident from congressional and public comment in the United States that there is a keen appreciation, particularly at the moment, of the risks of embarking on a gradually increasing military involvement in the Philippines, particularly given the history of the involvement in Vietnam.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the statements made by the former Ombudsman, Professor Richardson, as reported in the Age of 22 January 1986, relating to the failure of the Government to provide adequate funding or staff to enable the Ombudsman to carry out his obligations imposed on him by Parliament under the 1983 amending Freedom of Information Bill. Firstly, is it correct that the Government has failed to supply the funding and staff, as alleged? Secondly, is this part of Senator Walsh's campaign to diminish the strength and usage of the FOI Act? Thirdly, what action is the Government taking to remedy the situation? Fourthly, is it a fact that Professor Richardson's period of office terminated more than two months ago and that he has not yet been replaced? Fifthly, was this vacancy at all times known to the Government and why has the replacement not been made immediately? Sixthly, is this a further part of Senator Walsh's campaign to blunt the effectiveness of the Ombudsman in performing his FOI role?
—Order! The honourable senator's question is getting a bit long.

—There are three more matters; they are all related and the Minister has had notice of them. Seventhly, has the Attorney-General's report on FOI performance for 1984-85 been unavailable to the general public since its tabling late in the previous session? Eighthly, has this limited the opportunities of those preparing submissions to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for its three-year review of the FOI Act? Lastly, what involvement has Senator Walsh had in causing this deficiency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fortunately, I have had notice of Senator Missen's question and I have an answer. The answer, if I might horrify the Senate, is much longer than the question. Perhaps I can summarise it and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. The first part of the question related to the funding and staff of the Ombudsman's office. That was a crucial part of the question. The answer is that the Ombudsman's office has had its average operating staff level maintained when many government departments and authorities have had their staffing levels reduced during the present fiscal restraints. The Ombudsman's office staffing level over the past four years has been 52 in 1981-82, 55 in 1982-83, 60 in 1983-84 and 64 in 1984-85. The 1985-86 level is 68, although this includes for the first time the four statutory positions.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked in a number of parts of Senator Missen's question whether this is all part of some campaign by Senator Walsh. There is no such campaign and the answer to those parts of the question is no. Senator Walsh has views about these matters, as we all have, but they cannot be described effectively as a campaign. I hope Senator Walsh is not offended by that description.

It is true that Professor Richardson's period of office terminated two months ago; the vacancy has at all times been known to the Government, and it will be filled in due course. It has been filled in an acting capacity by an experienced Deputy Ombudsman. The Attorney-General's report on freedom of information performance has not been made available yet because of printing problems experienced by the Australian Government Publishing Service. However, the report has been cleared by the Attorney-General's Department for sale in late January; I think this is an old answer. I understand it is now available for purchase. As to the other parts of Senator Missen's question I seek leave to have the answers incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The answers read as follows-
1. ``Is it correct that the Government has failed to supply the funding and staff as alleged?''

The Ombudsman's office has had its average operating staffing level (AOSL) maintained when many Government departments and authorities have had their staffing level reduced during the present fiscal restraint. The Ombudsman's office staffing levels over the past four years have been: 52 in 1981-82, 55 in 1982-83, 60 in 1983-84 and 64 in 1984-85. The 1985-86 level is 68, although this includes for the first time, the four statutory positions which means, effectively, no change in 1985-86 compared with 1984-85.
2. ``Is this part of Senator Walsh's campaign to diminish the strength and usage of the FOI Act?''
There is no such campaign.
3. ``What action is the Government taking to remedy the situation?''
The staffing of the Ombudsman's Office is constantly under review to meet needs as required as is the case with all Commonwealth departments and agencies.

The Government notes that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is undertaking a review of the FOI Act this year. The review will include the question of costs and efficiency in the administration of the Act and the weighing of future benefits against future costs.
4. ``Is it a fact that Professor Richardson's period of office terminated more than two months ago and that he has not yet been replaced?''
Yes.
5. ``Was this vacancy at all times known to the Government and why has the replacement not been made immediately?''

Yes. The Government is aware of the vacancy and has taken steps, through advertising and other avenues, to ensure that a wide range of people are considered. It is important that the person selected possess the personal and administrative qualities appropriate to meet the Government's wish that the appointment be of the highest calibre. There has been no disruption to the role of the Ombudsman because the position has been filled continuously by an experienced Deputy Ombudsman, Air Vice Marshal Jordan, who has acted as Ombudsman since the retirement of Professor Richardson.
6. ``Is this a further part of Senator Walsh's campaign to blunt the effectiveness of the Ombudsman in performing his FOI role?''
There has been no such campaign either by Senator Walsh or by the Government.
7. ``Has the Attorney-General's report on FOI performance for 1984-85 been unavailable to the general public since its tabling late in the previous session?''

Yes. Unavoidable printing problems have been experienced by the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS). However, Attorney-General's Department cleared the FOI Report with AGPS for sale in late January. It is now available for purchase.
8. ``Has this limited the opportunities of those preparing submissions to the Senate constitutional and legal affairs committee for its three-year review of the FOI Act?''

The Senate Standing Committee advertised widely in December, inviting written submissions from all interested members of the public. Anyone wishing to lodge a submission has the opportunity to do so. If any person feels that he or she has been disadvantaged in any way in this context, I am sure the Secretary to the Standing Committee would view sympathetically any application to lodge a late submission.
9. ``What involvement has Senator Walsh played in causing this deficiency?''
In line with answers to questions 2 and 6 above, Senator Walsh has had no involvement in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science. What does the Government propose to do about the serious and potentially life-threatening inadequacies of the Australian weather forecasting system? Does the Minister agree with the long time director of the Queensland Bureau of Meteorology, Mr Arch Shields, that Australia is placing far too much emphasis on satellites, computers and automatic weather stations, all of which can and do malfunction, for its weather forecasting, virtually ignoring the vital role played by trained weather observers on the ground? Is the Government concerned that too many forecasts are now being issued with the rider `meteorologists warn that this forecast is based on inadequate information'?

—I am aware of current concern about changes to the weather forecasting system. I am not aware of the views of Arch Shields but, of course, there are changes in the methods of weather forecasting; the satellite is of use in that respect, as are computers. In his time, Indigo Jones was of use in respect of weather forecasting and maybe Mr Arch Shields belongs to the Indigo Jones school. I do not know. I will get a more detailed answer from the Minister for Science on the more specific elements of the honourable senator's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. I refer to the recently released Sax report on nursing within Canberra public hospitals, which concludes that patient care has deteriorated to such an extent that babies are not receiving rostered feeds and patients are at risk through the breakdown in our hospital system. This is a totally unacceptable situation. Other than merely referring the report to the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, what action will the Government take to rectify this scandalous situation? How long will it take to implement some real solutions?

—Senator Reid asked me a question about the report of the Sax Independent Inquiry into Nursing Services within the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. My briefing from the Minister indicates that the report is receiving consideration by the Government. It was dated 31 January 1986 and identifies a number of issues for management attention as well as the problems that have been raised by the Royal Australian Nursing Federation relating to staffing problems in the Australian Capital Territory hospital system. As well as identifying the problems of a local nature that have been referred to, the report reflects the Australia-wide problem confronting the nursing profession and the need to take measures on a broad front to overcome these problems. The Australian Capital Territory Health Authority is already taking steps to solve some of these problems, particularly those of a local nature, within its existing confines. It has set up a joint review team to review such matters as nurse recruitment, career structure, skills mix, education, child care and facilities and the like. On the broader issue, the Authority is involved in discussions with the Public Service Board and the Department of Veterans' Affairs, because there are nine hospitals within the responsibility of my portfolio, about the need to develop a better career structure for nurses in Commonwealth hospitals. The more precise terms of the Sax inquiry are receiving the urgent consideration of the Government and we will be in a position shortly to make a full disclosure of the Government's acceptance or otherwise of the recommendations.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of reports in yesterday's media regarding the release of the Business Council of Australia's economic statement? What is the Minister's reaction to the warning from the BCA that this Labor Government's policy of tight money and high interest rates is threatening to cut Australia's prospects for economic growth and future investment? Is the Government prepared to take the advice of this very pertinent report which suggests a reduction of the Budget deficit by at least $500m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator Bjelke-Petersen for drawing my attention to statements made by the Business Council of Australia because I recall very well a statement that the Business Council made last week about the coalition's wages policy. The Business Council said essentially that it would be a catastrophe for the country if the coalition's wages policy were ever to be inflicted on it. I note also for the record that that discussion in which the BCA bucketed the coalition was then promptly leaked by some of Mr Howard's colleagues. I do not know whether it was the ideologues or the wets, the wets or the dries, who leaked the record of that discussion but I suppose that both groups have reason to feel aggrieved with Mr Howard because they now realise that they made a terrible mistake in electing him as leader. The ideologues voted for him and then found out that he went to water as soon as he got into the position. So none of the wets, dries or pragmatists are satisfied with the present Leader of the Liberal Party.

ANSWER.PARA: I suggest to Senator Bjelke-Petersen, in response to her question, that the coalition would be well advised to take notice of the Business Council of Australia's views on wages policy and to dump the disastrous policy being advocated by the present coalition leader, which he himself says will lead to five years of industrial warfare. In regard to the statement reported yesterday, I did see on my desk a piece of paper from the Business Council of Australia and I had a quick glance at it. I particularly agreed with the last paragraph which referred to the way in which the States collectively have undermined the Commonwealth Government's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any State in particular?

—No State in particular; it just identified the States in general. Of course, no State has done so much to undermine the Commonwealth Government's economic strategy and minimise its success as the State Government of Queensland. It is dragging the rest of the country down, of course not quite to the Queensland Government level because the arithmetic cannot work out that way, but certainly it is dragging the rest of the country down. As to the need to cut $500m off the deficit, I do not think that anybody who knows anything about it would argue that one can be so precise, within a few hundred million dollars, about the size any particular deficit ought to be, but I can tell Senator Bjelke-Petersen that the policies that her leader, the Leader of the Opposition, is advocating-that is, to throw away anything up to $1 1/2 billion in revenue and spend an extra $1 1/2 billion revenue via that irresponsible shopping list of promises he has made, which would lead to increased expenditure-would lead not to a reduction in the deficit but to a blow out in the deficit of the order of $3 billion or $4 billion which would bring him back to the sort of prospective deficit that the current Government inherited from him. I remind Senator Bjelke-Petersen that, if she is really concerned about the size of the deficit, she ought to repudiate all the revenue and expenditure promises that the coalition has made over the last couple of years.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry to the vine pull scheme which was initiated to allow grape growers under financial stress to withdraw gradually from the industry and to which the Federal Government has allocated something of the order of $7.5m. Is the Minister aware that in South Australia some 500 inquiries, representing 25 per cent of the grape growers in South Australia, have been received concerning this vine pull scheme and that 135 definite applications have been received to date? Will the Government give serious and immediate consideration to extending the 30 May 1986 deadline for applications to the scheme in order to allow grape growers under financial stress time to make a considered and correct decision regarding the future direction of their livelihood after this year's vintage?

—Senator Jessop gave me some notice that he would ask a question like this but unfortunately his correspondence was sent through the internal post and it did not arrive in my office until half past twelve. I have not been able to get any information from Mr Kerin for that reason. I will pass the question on and provide Senator Jessop with an answer.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In view of the extremely large number of people coming to this country from New Zealand, many of whom immediately receive the unemployment benefit, costing this country in excess of $60m a year, does the Government intend to continue the open door policy it has with regard to people coming from New Zealand? If the Government does not intend to change this crazy policy, will the Minister table in the Senate figures detailing the number of New Zealanders who have arrived in this country over the last five years, the number who have received unemployment benefits and the cost to the Australian taxpayer of those benefits?

—I have not at hand figures on the number of New Zealanders coming to Australia or the number of New Zealanders who receive unemployment benefits. I point out to Senator Townley that what he describes as this crazy policy has been the crazy policy of successive governments from both sides of the Parliament.
—All governments are crazy.

—The honourable senator may well think that all governments are crazy. I will get the information that Senator Townley seeks. All I know is that last time he asked a question like this I think it concerned the number of supporting parent benefits we paid in Fiji or somewhere. It turned out that it involved one person in the whole of Oceania.
—That is absolutely untrue.

—If it was not him, it was someone else; someone like him! Senator Townley is well known in this place for his xenophobia. I remember that he used to get upset about portable pensions. I have not noticed him being upset about that lately. He used to object to us paying pensions overseas to everyone except ex-parliamentarians and Sir John Kerr. He said that everyone else should be banned from receiving such pensions. I will seek the information from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The matter of our policies and relationships with New Zealand should probably be referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I will check on that.

—Does the Minister representing the Treasurer have recent official indicators of the current position of the Australian economy? Do the economic indicators show that the strong economic recovery which has been occurring in Australia over the past three years is continuing? Why are bankruptcies rising in Queensland but falling in Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The easiest part of the question to answer is the last part. The answer to the question why bankruptcies are rising in Queensland and falling in Western Australia is self-evident. Queensland has a National Party government and Western Australia has a Labor government, recently re-elected, if I may observe in passing, by a vote which, if repeated in a Federal election, would have increased the Labor Party majority in every Federal seat held by the Labor Party in Western Australia. So, there is absolutely no joy for the Western Australian Liberal Party, or the Collins Street clique which temporarily controls it, in the result of the Western Australian State election.

ANSWER.PARA: In response more directly to the question asked by Senator Maguire, let me say that this Government has been in office for almost three years. Throughout that period, leaving aside only the few months crank-up period that it took to reverse the disastrous trends which had been established by Mr Howard when he was Treasurer, the country has enjoyed economic growth approaching 5 per cent a year. The present indications are that that growth rate is continuing.

To select just some of the more recent economic statistics, the unemployment rate fell from 7.9 per cent in November to 7.8 per cent in December. Manufacturing production rose by a further 2.4 per cent in the September quarter, which made it 5.2 per cent higher than it was a year previously. The value of retail sales rose by 1.2 per cent in October and by 3.4 per cent in the three months to October. The number of new motor vehicle registrations rose strongly in November to an annual figure which, incidentally, was a record, although admittedly there was some decline-in case somebody from the Opposition is aware of this-in motor vehicle registrations for the month of December. Nevertheless, motor vehicle registrations, like building approvals, remain at levels which are historically high and certainly extraordinarily high compared with the very depressed levels of three years ago. Because of this economic growth, the number of people employed has increased by more than 500,000 in less than three years, which is even more jobs than the present Leader of the Opposition managed to destroy in 12 months when he was Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Finance, follows the reply he gave to a question asked by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The Minister stated that it was the Government's policy to let the Australian dollar find its own level. Does the Minister for Finance deny that his Government has kept interest rates in Australia high to support the Australian dollar and to stop it falling even further than it has? If he agrees that that has been so, does his answer to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle mean that interest rates will now be eased and that the Australian dollar will, in fact, be allowed to find its own level?

—This Government is following a broadly based approach to macro-economic management. The three legs which support our economic policy are expenditure restraint, which the previous Government, for all its windy rhetoric, failed to practise for the last five years of its existence, a wages policy which has led to real labour unit costs falling to the lowest level at which they have been for 15 years and industrial disputes falling to the lowest level at which they have resided for 15 years, and so on.
—Interest rates are at their highest level.

—No, Senator Jessop, I keep telling you that interest rates reached their record level in May 1982 when Mr Howard was Treasurer and when the 90-day bank bill rate rose to 22 per cent. Senator Jessop likes talking about real interest rates. Any fool can get real interest rates down by pushing inflation up, and that is exactly what Mr Howard did.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I interject occasionally, but I object to being mistaken for my twin brother, Senator Messner.
—If you did interject, Senator Jessop, it was clearly out of order.

—I certainly apologise to Senator Jessop if I did that. The point is that this Government has a balanced approach to macro-economic management based on and supported by those three legs, whereas the previous Government ran monetary policy and nothing else. It had no wages policy. It walked away from any wages policy in May 1981, which led to a wages explosion, both in that calendar year and in the next calendar year, of 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively, an inflation rate of 11 1/2 per cent and an unemployment rate also in double figures. As I said, despite all its bold rhetoric, simultaneously--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister was asked a question about interest rates. He has not addressed the question of interest rates at all. He is debating economic policy generally. I ask you to bring him to order and to ask him to answer the question.
—I ask the Minister not to debate the question but to come to the purport of the answer.

—Certainly, Mr President. Indeed, I do not think there is much more that I need to say on the subject, except that this Government is running a well thought through and highly successful economic policy.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister again: Does he deny that the Government has kept interest rates high to support the Australian dollar and does his previous answer indicate that that policy has now changed and that we will see a reduction of interest rates in Australia?

—I can understand Senator Chaney's desire, I suppose, to have me make predictions about where interest rates are going and when. However, I am not going to do any such thing, because I can remember that poli- ticians sometimes get into trouble if they do things like that. For example, I remember the Deputy Prime Minister, as he then was, in 1977 asserting that if interest rates did not fall by 2 per cent by the end of the year he would eat his hat. Instead of falling by 2 per cent, interest rates went up by, I think, 3 or 4 per cent. It is certainly not my practice to make predictions about future movements in interest rates, let alone put a time-frame on them.

—Does the Minister representing the Attorney-General agree that an identity problem similar to that being experienced by children of adoptive parents could well arise with artificially conceived children using donor materials? Can the Minister guarantee that, if such a problem arose, sufficient information about the donor parents would have been recorded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems quite reasonable to assume that children born as a result of the use of donor sperm will, like adopted children, want to know about their origins, including, in some cases, identifying information about a biological parent. The report of the Family Law Council on reproductive technology, which was tabled by the Attorney-General last August, firmly puts the view that these children are in an analogous position to that of adopted children. The Council considers that the lessons learnt in the adoption area about the importance of honesty in family relationships for the healthy development of children should be heeded.

ANSWER.PARA: Recommendation No. 9 of the Family Law Council report recommends, I am told, that, in recognition of the importance of access to knowledge and information of genealogical origins, legislation and practice should provide for access to such information by the child or adult, that such information be of a non- identifying nature prior to the child reaching 18 years of age and that identifying information be available for adults over 18 years of age. The Attorney-General has before him this and other related recommendations put forward by the Council and will no doubt be responding in due course.

As to the latter part of the question, the Attorney advises me that the Commonwealth is not in a position to guarantee that sufficient information about a child's genetic origins will be available if required at a later date, because it does not have the legislative power to do so. I should finally mention that the Government is considering the recent report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on in vitro fertilisation and the status of children. That recommends, among other things, that pending possible establishment of a national advisory body, as recommended by the Family Law Council, the question of record keeping and access to information relating to donors should be considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to an article in the Age of 11 February 1986 concerning the comments of Mr Gerry Hand, the member for Melbourne, on the Federal Government's intentions concerning Aboriginal land rights legislation. Given the statement by Mr Brian Burke prior to the West Australian election that he would resign if the Federal Government imposed land rights legislation on Western Australia, and given the Prime Minister's response that he had no problems with Mr Burke's position on land rights and that he did not expect that the Labor Party would be losing Mr Burke, can the Minister say whether the Prime Minister's comments are to be interpreted as meaning that there will be no Federal land rights legislation? If that was not the meaning conveyed by the Prime Minister's comments, is it still the Federal Government's intention to introduce uniform Federal land rights legislation? Noting the reference in the Age to a Federal Government decision to pursue a State by State approach to land rights legislation, does this not imply that each of the States has different needs and conditions in relation to land rights? That being the case, would it not be more appropriate for the States and Territories to deal with land rights in their own legislation, thus ensuring local expertise and familiarity with the particular needs of the people of the State or Territory would result in the most appropriate legislation being enacted?

—I am advised by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, that when he announced the Government's decision on the preferred model, which is a State by State model, in August last year he indicated that there were to be further discussions with Aboriginals, States, and the Northern Territory Government and other interest groups and that he would report back to Cabinet in the earlier part of this year. Those processes of discussion have been set in place and are well advanced and Mr Holding expects to be in a position to report to Cabinet within a few weeks. Until there has been that report back to Cabinet and Cabinet discussion and decisions in relation to it, there is nothing further to add to the statements regarding land rights that have already been made by the Prime Minister and Mr Holding.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been brought to my attention that this week is the last week of broadcasting for Mr Kevin Chapman, a voice familiar to many Australians through his long association with parliamentary broadcasts on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. He has been on the air continuously since 1942 and has been broadcasting the Parliament since 1957. Kevin and his brother Ray, who commenced broadcasting in 1938 and retired last year, hold the world record for brothers in broadcasting-over 90 years.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Chapman has had a most interesting career in broadcasting and television. He was involved in television in this country from its outset in 1956 and maintained his participation in that medium until 1984. He was radio supervisor at the Melbourne Olympic Games in 1956. He broadcast for NHK Tokyo in Japan in 1966-67 and for Blue Danube Radio, Vienna, in 1983 and 1985. I personally have had a long association with Mr Chapman. As a former Minister for the Media and now as President of the Senate, I wish to pay a warm tribute to him for his great contribution to broadcasting in this country, and particularly for his service to parliamentary broadcasting. I am sure that all honourable senators join me in extending best wishes to Kevin, his wife Pamela and their family. We trust that he will have a healthy and enjoyable retirement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to associate the Government and Government senators with your comments, Mr President, and your tribute to Mr Chapman. Probably the nicest, shortest thing I can say is that when one sometimes has the good fortune to be absent from the Senate when it is sitting, it is a great pleasure to hear Mr Chapman. That is more than I can say of a lot of other people that I hear on the same program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in his comments and indeed you in yours, Mr President, I am somewhat nonplussed as the Leader of the Government stole my joke. I imagine that we do not get a lot of jokes in here--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am so overcome with emotion at Mr Chapman's leaving that I have put my foot in it. I wish Mr Chapman well in his retirement, which I understand he is undertaking most reluctantly. I am sure that many of the listeners to these broadcasts will wish that some of us were retiring and not Mr Chapman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I associate my Party, the Australian Democrats, with your tribute, Mr President, to Mr Kevin Chapman. I was amazed when I received your note on this matter, for which I thank you. I said to the Assistant Clerk at the Table: `Chapman? He is only about 50-odd or in his late forties, isn't he?' That in itself is a tribute because every time I see him and pay my greetings to him, he always has a pleasant smile and a happy retort. It confounds me that someone who has been imprisoned in a semi-darkened chamber, as he has been for 29 years reporting Parliament, still maintains his sanity, let alone his sense of humour. Mr Chapman has done that and has done so remarkably well.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chapman dignifies this place with his quiet, detached description of events. Perhaps the most distinguished thing about him and of the greatest credit to him is that he has been able to restrain himself in describing some events in this place which, to say the least, should not have happened let alone have been described. I am sure that I would not have the capability or the mental discipline to be able to do what Mr Chapman has done over the years. He has carried out his task with great distinction and I compliment him.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I also wish to be associated with the remarks made by you, Mr President, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp). As has been indicated, Mr Chapman is to those in this place but a shadowy figure behind darkened glass, but to the millions of people we think are out there listening to our every word, he is something more than that. He is the person who interprets events quite impartially in this place. As Senator Chipp said, probably many times he has been tempted to go far beyond his brief when things have gone a little awry in this chamber and in the other place. Service as long as 29 years certainly puts him in the ranks of the fathers of this institution as we call it-probably even more so than you, Mr President. Nonetheless, he has seen many things happen and it is noteworthy that he has been able to undertake his job in such a distinguished and skilled manner over many years. I wish him well in his retirement. As Senator Chipp said, obviously Mr Chapman is getting out with his sanity intact. I hope he will have many years of happy retirement. I am not sure what he will be doing when Parliament is being broadcast. I rather suspect he will be listening to FM broadcasts, cricket or something along those lines.

—by leave-I, too, would like to associate myself with your remarks, Mr President, and the remarks of other senators on the retirement of Kevin Chapman from his position as broadcaster of Federal Parliament. As other senators have observed, Kevin has brought to that task over many years a dignity and a rounded voice which often does not emanate in like manner from many of us. I, too, wondered about his being able to keep his sanity, and clearly he has been able to do so; he is a most personable man. SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to pass on to Australian motorists, farmers and other consumers the full benefit of the drop in world oil prices.

When the present Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, was seeking a mandate from the Australian people to form the Government-which he received from them in March 1983-he made a very significant promise which is very relevant to the subject we are discussing today. Every sector of the Australian community and every Australian, most of whom are motorists in one form or another and who are engaged in virtually every form of industry in Australia, is affected by that great broken promise of Prime Minister Hawke on petrol prices.

The Government is about to make another dramatic switch in policies which it has been pursuing. It is clear from statements that have been made over the last few weeks, particularly by the Prime Minister and also by many other Ministers including the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, who is at the table, that the Government is desperately seeking some way of avoiding passing on to Australians the full benefit of the very considerable decrease in world oil prices which has occurred over the last month or so. We believe that the Senate will give support to that principle. It is a very great entitlement of Australian people, one which this Government looks set to repudiate or to qualify in some very major way. It is our responsibility as legislators to give a very clear message to the Government on behalf of all Australians-I do not mean just farmers or industry; I mean all Australians-who have been paying these higher and higher prices for fuel and petrol under this Government, that they should now receive the benefit of the lower prices which are available all around the world.

It is a very simple principle indeed and it flows from the policy which has been followed by successive governments in Australia since 1979 that Australians should be paying world prices for their petrol. Until then, of course, Australians enjoyed a very low price for petrol. But I think one of the major contributions of the Fraser Government to responsible government in this country was that it adopted the policy in 1979 that Australians should be paying the world price for petrol, and not be allowed the very special low price that they had been getting up until then. The policy, which has been known as the import parity pricing policy, was really a formula which gave effect to the principle of world prices. That was the way the world price was to be ascertained. I might say that leading figures in the present Government-I am thinking particularly of the Treasurer, Mr Keating and the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, and others-were highly critical of that responsible approach of the Fraser Government. We can recall statements by Mr Keating in particular about every petrol pump being made a branch of the tax office and so on. However, when the Australian Labor Party came to government it embraced that policy with great enthusiasm and it has pursued it to its great advantage because of the ever increasing revenues that it has obtained by following it. One thing that is very clear and very basic to that policy is that if Australians are asked to pay world prices, if those prices go up, unfortunately they will have to pay more. However, when those prices go down they are clearly entitled to the benefit of that reduced price. It is of elementary fairness, apart altogether from economic considerations, that that should be so. That fact was perceived by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, when he was Opposition spokesman on minerals and energy. Referring to the then policy he stated:
Government policy ties Australian petrol prices to the price of crude oil from Saudi Arabia.
That was the way it was measured under the import parity pricing formula. He continued:
Any fall in the Saudi price must be passed on to Australian motorists in lower petrol prices.

All we are asking at the moment-we are asking no more and no less-is that when, as now, the price of oil throughout the world falls to the extent it has, and the people around the world are already enjoying the benefit of those falling prices, as Mr Keating said, they must be passed on to Australian motorists in lower petrol prices. Obviously Mr Keating is about to repudiate that very simple and very fair principle. From his remarks yesterday in the House of Representatives it is clear that that is the way the Government is going and that is the way the Minister for Resources and Energy is clearly thinking. His overseas interviews have been reported widely and he has been reported in interviews in Australia as indicating the great difficulties the Government will have in applying fairly the world parity price for petrol. In recent journals Senator Evans seems to have coined another of his famous phrases. We can remember some of them from the past but the one of the present is this: He says that there is a lot more room for taxation at the pump. That is a refrain we have been hearing and will hear a lot more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Senator Evans has been quoted in two recent journals-Australian Business and Australian Business Review-as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a lot more room for taxation at the pump.
Here is the thinking of this Government and the thinking of its Minister for Resources and Energy.

Clearly, the Government is doing very nicely out of high petrol prices in this country. From the crude oil levy and the petrol excise duty the Government is getting over $6 billion a year in revenue and it will not give it away. That is precisely the way it is thinking and it is expressed in that quote from Senator Evans. As I said, that it why it is imperative that Australians should be outraged and should express their outrage. We, as senators, should express our outrage on their behalf and demand that having paid higher and higher prices for fuel-as I have said we have paid at least 10c a litre more for petrol during the life of this Government; and there are various reasons for that which I will deal with in a minute-when prices start to go down we are entitled to the lower price now. That very simple, elementary principle has been recognised by Mr Bob Brown who is the chairman of the Government's back-benchers' economic committee. Bob Brown can see the truth. Senator Evans cannot see it; Treasurer Keating cannot see it; Prime Minister Hawke and Senator Button-we have had all the shilly shallying from them over the last few days-do not seem to be able to see it either. On 4 February this year Mr Bob Brown stated:
The Federal Government had a duty to motorists who had put up with rising petrol prices under the import parity formula without complaint.
To fail now to honour an undertaking to follow the IPP policy when it falls will cause serious damage to the Government's credibility.

Of course it will cause serious damage to the Government's credibility; it has already caused serious damage to the Government's credibility. Despite those very strong words of Bob Brown and despite the outrage that has already occurred, the Government will persist in repudiating the very elements of the policy which it has been following.

The policy of world parity pricing for Australian oil is, as I have said, one which the Opposition developed when in government and we have followed it when in opposition. We have supported that policy; we supported it in principle last year even when the price of petrol was going up as a result of it. I think the fact was recognised by many people in Australia that it was necessary that that policy should be adhered to in bad times as well as in good times. However, now that those prices are falling very considerably, Australians must have the benefit of that fall. As I have said, the Government cannot simply take the benefit of higher prices yet deny Australians relief when prices are lower. Such a policy, which this government seems to be embarking upon, is nothing short of outrageous.

The first of March is the next date on which the Government will fix the price of petrol. It is now considering the matter and is about to welsh on its promise. The best estimate of the world price of oil at the moment is about $20 a barrel-I think this would be a fair price to take. Australian motorists, Australian farmers and Australians generally would be looking forward to a reduction of about 7c a litre in the price of petrol and an equivalent reduction in the price of diesel. For the average motorist that reduction would be reflected in petrol costing $3 a week less. These are very significant figures for a great variety of economic reasons. They are significant from the point of view of inflation and inputs for industry and desperately significant from the point of view of our rural industry. However, I do not want to emphasise any of these economic arguments. I emphasise that, having paid the higher prices for petrol for several years-as Mr Bob Brown said, having paid them uncomplainingly particularly over the last year-now that prices have gone down, in elementary fairness Australians are entitled to get the benefit of the lower prices. They are entitled to receive a fair go from this Government and it is about to deprive them of that fair go.

Yesterday we heard Senator Evans say in the Senate-we have read about this in various interviews that have been given not only by him but also by the Prime Minister and in briefings to the Press; it is now becoming absolutely notorious; that the Government will take the view that it cannot afford the loss of revenue. Because of this great dependence on revenue from fuel, which has become a feature of the Government's budgeting, it cannot afford a reduction in petrol prices of that order. That sort of argument simply will not wash. In the last three years the Government has been increasing its revenue in real terms. Every year there has been a significant increase in government revenue from one source or another, particularly from fuel. Its total additional revenue amounts to about $5 1/2 billion. The Government is now saying that it cannot afford a loss of $1 billion or so which would result from passing onto Australians the 7c a litre reduction in petrol prices. But it has had these large increases. As I said, over $5 billion was received and the Government has spent that on its program. Last year alone it received over $500m in increased revenue from fuel and oil which it had not bargained on.

Yesterday I gave some figures about the increased costs of this Government. The Government's administrative costs have greatly increased and are now hundreds of millions of dollars more than they were under the Fraser Government. These are simply the Government's costs of administration. As I pointed out yesterday in a debate on the Trade Practices Amendment Bill, its costs of the regulation of business are $700m a year at the very least-and probably $1 billion a year. By its vastly increased revenues the Government has acquired an ease with which to accommodate the sort of decrease in revenue which it says it now cannot afford. The Government should have been planning for this.

Senator Gareth Evans yesterday gave the impression that everyone was surprised by this sudden drop in oil prices. The experts around the world have been saying for more than 12 months that oil prices would fall. The dogs have been barking it all around the world. Senator Evans says he has just been around the world and he knows how surprised everybody was. I do not know who he was talking to, but I have been in Australia for those 12 months and I have been reading what people have been saying and forecasting. The oil industry itself has been concerned about it for some time. It has been known for 12 months. The Government's tax package last September must have taken into account the possible revenue implications of falling oil prices, the very thing that has now happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —What were they doing?

—They were not doing their job or they just could not care less. Government members just want more money to make big fellows of themselves. They talk about tax cuts. What is the good of a tax cut if everybody has to pay virtually the same amount in increased petrol costs? It is a fraud. It is said that the Government was surprised. The Minister, Senator Evans, should resign. If he did not know and could not advise what was going to happen, he should have resigned already. The planning should have taken this into account. All Australians are entitled to this reduction and they should be demanding it, and we should be supporting this motion.
